- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/526539/6/ : SUCCESS in 2h 47m 32s'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-01-04 02:10:24.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-1 by Tetsuro Nakamura <nakamura.tetsuro@lab.ntt.co.jp>
'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-01-04 20:00:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

Have we identified a place where we are going to need this information **on the compute node**? I don't actually see any place this information would be useful or needed."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-04 23:06:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-04 23:11:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

@Jay: I had totally envisioned PowerVMComputeDriver.update_provider_tree being the thing to manage our shared storage pool RPs, at least by default.  (This is what we do today; it allows us to use our SSPs with nova out of the box without having to have some other orchestrator sitting on top.)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-05 05:57:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-01-05 12:16:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

We should probably have a broader conversation about the management of sharing providers with the ProviderTree and the passing of it into the virt driver.

I can see the value of such things for the virt drivers like PowerVM and vCenter where rather a lot could be happening, and there is access, in the driver to lots of information like shared network and storage resources. If we insist that the virt driver is not allowed to talk to placement itself, then it is a useful work around the barrier.

However, it makes the ProviderTree this mass of all kinds of stuff that is being passed back and forth across an arbitrary barrier.

I would _much_ rather allow the complex virt drivers to talk to placement if they feel like it. If a driver were out of tree there's nothing we could do to prevent such a thing. And any resource management system that is not nova and has an admin token can do whatever it likes with placement.

So it strikes me as a strange limitation ensures the resource tracker has to be complex. It would be handy if we could allow virt drivers to manage (and contain) that complexity themselves.

If we can't do placement from within the virt driver, then I still think we need to assume and expect that there will be third party agents of the virt _system_ which is going to be manipulating some of the stuff that is shared.

My earlier +1 was because I'm assumed this was an already decided thing."}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-01-05 12:23:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with check hyper-v

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com//nova/526539/7/ : FAILURE in 4h 39m 10s'}, {'account_id': 9172, 'date': '2018-01-05 12:45:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I agree with Chris that it would be handy if virt drivers can talk to placement and if we try to prevent this it would be quite artificial. In the VMware case we could have shared resources which change dynamically and it would be useful if we can account them in the virt driver itself rather than creating out of band tools which talk to placement.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-05 14:43:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-05 15:13:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> My earlier +1 was because I'm assumed this was an already decided thing.

It was.  But y'all raise very valid points.  Let's hash it out again at the sched meeting on Monday."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-01-05 15:51:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

OK, PowerVM and vCenter are apparently good examples of where this functionality would be used on the compute nodes. Good with me.

Chris, in response to your statement:

"However, it makes the ProviderTree this mass of all kinds of stuff that is being passed back and forth across an arbitrary barrier."

a couple things...

First of all, it's not an arbitrary barrier :) It's the virt driver API, and specifically a single proposed method (update_provider_tree()) of that API. So I wouldn't exactly say it's "arbitrary".

Secondly, Eric and I have done some recent refactoring of the ProviderTree object/API itself to make it much more rigid (in the face of concurrent use) and made it hard to abuse (e.g. the internal _Provider objects are no longer returned or accessible). So, given a choice of a wild-west sort of situation where each virt driver is communicating with the placement service itself (and the inevitable duplication of lots of code like auth'ing, microversions, etc), I would vastly prefer the ProviderTree being the thing that the virt driver modifies (again, via the ProviderTree's rigid, thread-safe API) and leave the communication with the placement service to the reportclient.

Thoughts?

-jay'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-05 16:03:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I don't mind the idea of having intra-nova placement work funneled through this spot for the reasons stated (thread safety, code commonality) as long as we're not doing it with the expectation that e.g. OOT drivers have to conform."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-01-05 16:04:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Trying to check my understanding of this stuff, some questions:

Suppose the virt driver is aware of a shared disk resource foo and wants to use it. When it receives a bare-bones provider tree, it can add shared disk resource foo to it. When the provider tree goes back to the resource tracker, will the resource tracker create that shared provider? If yes, what about other compute nodes that also use the same shared storage under the hood, what manages the race. If no, who does the creating?

Also, if yes, why isn't e.g. cinder responsible for that?"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-01-05 16:23:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Trying to check my understanding of this stuff, some questions:
 > 
 > Suppose the virt driver is aware of a shared disk resource foo and
 > wants to use it. When it receives a bare-bones provider tree, it
 > can add shared disk resource foo to it. When the provider tree goes
 > back to the resource tracker, will the resource tracker create that
 > shared provider? If yes, what about other compute nodes that also
 > use the same shared storage under the hood, what manages the race.
 > If no, who does the creating?
 > 
 > Also, if yes, why isn't e.g. cinder responsible for that?

Great questions.

The virt driver is already responsible for communicating inventory changes for a resource provider (the existing get_inventory() virt driver method). I think it's natural to allow the virt driver to create new child resource providers of a parent that it knows about -- and manage the inventory records of those child providers -- via the ProviderTree interface. In fact, that's what the ProviderTree interface was built for: allowing the quick lookup of provider information by name or UUID and setting inventory information for a provider.

With regards to allowing the virt driver to create new *root* resource providers through the ProviderTree interface (i.e. create new sharing providers), I don't necessarily see a huge problem with that. If an out-of-tree provider wants to create a new sharing provider it's going to do that anyway, and we might as well make that something that is done in a consistent way via the ProviderTree instead of the OOT virt drivers duplicating code.

The only thing I'm *not* keen on is allowing the ProviderTree any functionality with regards to *allocations*. Only the scheduler/conductor should be writing allocation records. The virt drivers and compute node should only be concerned with ensuring accurate inventory and traits information.

Thoughts?

-jay

-jay"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-01-05 16:40:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> The virt driver is already responsible for communicating inventory
 > changes for a resource provider (the existing get_inventory() virt
 > driver method). I think it's natural to allow the virt driver to
 > create new child resource providers of a parent that it knows about
 > -- and manage the inventory records of those child providers -- via
 > the ProviderTree interface. In fact, that's what the ProviderTree
 > interface was built for: allowing the quick lookup of provider
 > information by name or UUID and setting inventory information for a
 > provider.

Yeah, that part is solid for me, I'm already taking that for granted. Once the nested-provider rubicon is crossed, this is sort of right and just.

 > With regards to allowing the virt driver to create new *root*
 > resource providers through the ProviderTree interface (i.e. create
 > new sharing providers), I don't necessarily see a huge problem with
 > that. If an out-of-tree provider wants to create a new sharing
 > provider it's going to do that anyway, and we might as well make
 > that something that is done in a consistent way via the
 > ProviderTree instead of the OOT virt drivers duplicating code.

(We wouldn't necessarily have to duplicate that much code if a virt driver could construct its own report client.)

While it might make sense to allow the Provider tree to do that root creation, the questions I raised before about coordination remain. And presumably, the creation of aggregates becomes something to be aware of it the virt driver becomes responsible, in effect, for telling something else to create a resource provider, but can't itself manage things.

 > The only thing I'm *not* keen on is allowing the ProviderTree any
 > functionality with regards to *allocations*. Only the
 > scheduler/conductor should be writing allocation records. The virt
 > drivers and compute node should only be concerned with ensuring
 > accurate inventory and traits information.

Rado probably has more details on this, but writing allocations, or at least _frequently_ managing a dynamic "reserved" value, is something that we very much want to do in a vmware clustered environment, because there are use cases for VMs that are not managed by OpenStack but are in the vcenter cluster. A logical way to deal with that is to make allocations, treating placement as a resource tracking tool, independent of nova (and even, to some extent, independent of OpenStack). That doesn't have to be done in the vmware virt driver, but that's one place where it would make sense.

In the very early days of talking about placement, especially with shared disk, it was pretty clear that one of the ways in which it would be cool was that multiple things could adjust inventory/allocations. Asserting that the one true way to manage allocations is centralized pieces of nova is, to me, a step in the wrong direction. I've got some more extended thoughts on this aspect of things that I need to write down somewhere, but have struggled to find the brain space. Will try to make it happen sooner than later. A lot of it is simply a hope to keep placement a generic thing.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-05 23:51:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> the questions I raised before about coordination remain. And 
> presumably, the creation of aggregates becomes something to be 
> aware of it the virt driver becomes responsible, in effect, for 
> telling something else to create a resource provider, but can't 
> itself manage things.

Right, this is something that needs to be dealt with regardless of what entity is doing the actual placement API calls.  To be explicit, consider a scenario where we're bootstrapping placement with a shared storage provider.  The SSP is shared by two compute nodes, both of which happen to hit update_provider_tree at the same time.  In the single-threaded view, each compute node would want to do something like:

- Create the SSP
- Assign traits to the SSP (at least MISC_SHARES_VIA_AGGREGATE)
- Associate the SSP with an aggregate
- Associate self (the compute node) with the aggregate
- Register the SSP's inventory

As long as the SSP's UUID is deterministic (that is, known and identical on all compute nodes beforehand), this would *almost* be covered by reacting properly to conflicts.  Example:

- X POSTs the SSP.  201.  Generation 0.
- Y POSTs the SSP with the same UUID.  409 (duplicate UUID).  Y reacts by GETting the provider record and its associations.  (Note: There's an intra-race here unless we implement a single atomic "get provider and associations" API - see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/521875/.)
- Y PUTs traits.  200.  Generation 1.
- X (still at generation 0) PUTs traits.  409.  X reacts by reGETting the provider and its associations, merging* the existing trait list with its own and (if changed) rePUTting.  200.  Generation 2.  (*"Merging" might actually be "replacing" - not sure.  Can we write this once in report client and have it always work and do the right thing?)
- Y (still at generation 1) PUTs aggregates.  409. (Actually, PUTting aggregates doesn't have generation support right now.  Need to add it.)  Here we face the "merge" question again, but this time it's harder because aggregates are just UUIDs.  No problem if the aggregate UUID is deterministic - we just ignore and move on.  But if the aggregate UUID isn't deterministic, we have no generic way to know whether the SSP is supposed to be associated with one aggregate or multiple - i.e. no way to know whether to merge or ignore.  (Note: For the PowerVM case I'm thinking of, we can make the aggregate UUID deterministic by reusing the SSP's UUID.  This works for us because one SSP:aggregate is always 1:1.  But I doubt we want that limitation across the board.)
- Similar scenario for registering/updating the SSP's inventory.  Here I think it's okay to react to 409 by blindly redriving, replacing whatever's in placement with what we know about the SSP's inventory.

Summary: To make "coordinated provider management" work, we need:
- [placement side] Generation support for PUT /resource_providers/{uuid}/aggregates
- [placement side] Single atomic API to get a provider and all its associations (traits, aggregates, inventory)
- [compute side] Logic to react appropriately to 409s for (at least) RP creation, traits, aggregates, inventory
- [compute side] To decide whether ^^ can be done generically enough to subsume it within report client, or if we need to allow virt more direct control'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-01-06 02:48:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with check hyper-v

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com//nova/526539/7/ : FAILURE in 7h 18m 14s'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-08 16:45:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

This was discussed in today's scheduler meeting [1].  The important points:

- Yes, we want to allow compute (via virt) to manage shared providers.  Known use cases in PowerVM and vCenter.
- We need to add generation to the aggregates APIs (cdent to propose).  (NB: When updating a provider's aggregates, only bump the generation of that one RP, not all of the aggregate's RPs.)
- Conflict trap/retry should happen at the high level.  That is, resource tracker should do driver.update_provider_tree and try to push the diffs wholesale.  On *any* conflict, redo the whole update_provider_tree-and-push-diffs procedure.  Comment left at [2].  (This is as opposed to doing retries at the low level, e.g. in the per-URI PUT wrappers.)
- Virt drivers managing shared providers will need to be careful when deleting them.  If ComputeDriver.update_provider_tree removes a provider, we'll (try to) delete it from placement.  So virt should just remove the aggregate association from the compute RP.  It should not remove the shared RP or change its aggregates.  (Report client then *might* remove the shared RP from the ProviderTree the next time it does a full refresh of compute-node-plus-associations.)  NOTE: This can result in leakage of sharing providers, which will have to be cleaned up through some other mechanism.
- The above (almost completely) removes any motivation to allow virt to talk to placement directly.  However, that topic was not discussed in and of itself and may still be brought up in the future.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova_scheduler/2018/nova_scheduler.2018-01-08-14.00.log.html
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/520246/19/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py@886"}, {'account_id': 6125, 'date': '2018-01-08 18:46:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

[{'created': '2017-12-07 23:26:11.000000000', 'message': 'Track associated sharing RPs in report client

With this change, SchedulerReportClient keeps track of any sharing
providers associated by aggregate with the compute node RP in the same
way as traits and aggregates.  Specifically:

- We use ProviderTree methods to save the information for each provider.

being that all of these associations should change out of band with
roughly the same frequency (i.e. very rarely).

commit_message:
Track associated sharing RPs in report client

With this change, SchedulerReportClient keeps track of any sharing
providers associated by aggregate with the compute node RP in the same
way as traits and aggregates.  Specifically:

- We use ProviderTree methods to save the information for each provider.
- We refresh sharing RP information along with aggregate and trait
  information whenever we "ensure" a provider exists.

Note that we also retrieve and track the aggregates and traits
associated with each sharing provider.

The refreshing (including cache expiry) of sharing RPs is done in the
same method with that of aggregate and trait associations.  The theory
being that all of these associations should change out of band with
roughly the same frequency (i.e. very rarely).

Change-Id: I840ebc7940e65af30e66d902bf360668ccb5a30e
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-18 17:16:11.000000000', 'message': 'Access Tempest config.CONF directly

This ensures that all Tempest plugin configs are loaded. Accessing it
via heat_tempest_plugin.config.CONF assumed that something else was
loading the plugin configs before we tried to access it. This is
probably only the case when running Tempest itself, but we want to be
able to discover and run tests from the heat_integrationtests without
going through Tempest.

Change-Id: I5e9325766ce166e62c731330c462c030cb1e11fc
'}]
commit_message:
Access Tempest config.CONF directly

This ensures that all Tempest plugin configs are loaded. Accessing it
via heat_tempest_plugin.config.CONF assumed that something else was
loading the plugin configs before we tried to access it. This is
probably only the case when running Tempest itself, but we want to be
able to discover and run tests from the heat_integrationtests without
going through Tempest.

Change-Id: I5e9325766ce166e62c731330c462c030cb1e11fc

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-19 22:40:41.000000000', 'message': 'Handle missing flavor.id in server response

Change Ie2d57029ad01cbe9e2b015857d6b95f77a97be19 introduced checks
for a servers flavor ID. This data is no longer returned after
Nova API microversion 2.46, causing problems for any tests/clients
requesting a higher version number.

Since these tests are not concerned with validating flavors, just
check if it is returned in the base class and skip the check if
it is not available.

Change-Id: Id7760cdfb9874014e03c7d8ebe269a03562bde18
Closes-bug: #1744401
'}]
commit_message:
Handle missing flavor.id in server response

Change Ie2d57029ad01cbe9e2b015857d6b95f77a97be19 introduced checks
for a servers flavor ID. This data is no longer returned after
Nova API microversion 2.46, causing problems for any tests/clients
requesting a higher version number.

Since these tests are not concerned with validating flavors, just
check if it is returned in the base class and skip the check if
it is not available.

Change-Id: Id7760cdfb9874014e03c7d8ebe269a03562bde18
Closes-bug: #1744401

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-18 10:15:59.000000000', 'message': "Restrict test_list_endpoints_for_token to tempest

The test_list_endpoints_for_token test now checks for services in
service_available, however that may include services from plugins.
We don't have a strong contract on the meaning of service_available
so this is not correct as it will look in the catalog for things
that may not even be OpenStack services.

Besides the test checks for service_available names in the catalog
so it does not honor the catalog_type setting that we have in
Tempest, so this test will not work if the catalog type is different
from the default value.

Fixing this by restring by services in Tempest (including keystone)
and checking for the catalog_type.

Change-Id: I32f4f056ea49fe04bfc309abe2cc9b9234b92847
Closes-bug: #1743996
"}, {'created': '2018-01-18 15:59:50.000000000', 'message': "Restrict test_list_endpoints_for_token to tempest

The test_list_endpoints_for_token test now checks for services in
service_available, however that may include services from plugins.
We don't have a strong contract on the meaning of service_available
so this is not correct as it will look in the catalog for things
that may not even be OpenStack services.

Fixing this by restring by services in Tempest (including keystone).

Change-Id: I32f4f056ea49fe04bfc309abe2cc9b9234b92847
Closes-bug: #1743996
"}, {'created': '2018-01-19 22:01:48.000000000', 'message': "Restrict test_list_endpoints_for_token to tempest

The test_list_endpoints_for_token test now checks for services in
service_available, however that may include services from plugins.
We don't have a strong contract on the meaning of service_available
so this is not correct as it will look in the catalog for things
that may not even be OpenStack services.

Fixing this by restricting by services in Tempest (including keystone).

Change-Id: I32f4f056ea49fe04bfc309abe2cc9b9234b92847
Closes-bug: #1743996
"}]
commit_message:
Restrict test_list_endpoints_for_token to tempest

The test_list_endpoints_for_token test now checks for services in
service_available, however that may include services from plugins.
We don't have a strong contract on the meaning of service_available
so this is not correct as it will look in the catalog for things
that may not even be OpenStack services.

Fixing this by restricting by services in Tempest (including keystone).

Change-Id: I32f4f056ea49fe04bfc309abe2cc9b9234b92847
Closes-bug: #1743996

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-12 07:18:26.000000000', 'message': "Remove oslo config global conf dependency

Ceilometer in Ocata made several changes to
remove oslo config's global conf requirement.

Instead ceilometer/service.py now creates a
oslo config object that gets passed to the
publisher.

Updated the monasca-ceilometer publisher with
additional conf argument.

Change-Id: Ieb7962a50fdb5d12ea6238c96ed116e8b2c83c48
"}, {'created': '2017-12-12 07:19:58.000000000', 'message': "Remove oslo config global conf dependency

Ceilometer in Ocata made several changes to
remove oslo config's global conf requirement.

See
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384834
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384624
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/386025

Instead ceilometer/service.py now creates a
oslo config object that gets passed to the
publisher.

Updated the monasca-ceilometer publisher with
additional conf argument.

Change-Id: Ieb7962a50fdb5d12ea6238c96ed116e8b2c83c48
"}, {'created': '2017-12-12 21:26:03.000000000', 'message': "Remove oslo config global conf dependency

Ceilometer in Ocata made several changes to
move away from  oslo config's global conf.
Instead ceilometer/service.py now creates a
oslo config object that gets passed to the
publisher.

To keep up with the changes had to make
the following changes in monasca-ceilometer
1.) Monasca Publisher now extends
ConfigPublisherBase, with conf as argument
2.) monasca_client now takes conf as an
argument during intialization.
3.) Added monasca_ceilometer_opts to
intialize all ConfigOpts. This will have
to be regiested in ceilometer/opts.py.
(will need a additional line in opts.py)
4.) Introduced three new properties
service_username, service_password and
service_auth_url since username, password
and auth_url were removed from
[service_credentials] section.

List of Ceilometer changes to remove
global conf
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384834
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384624
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/386025

Change-Id: Ieb7962a50fdb5d12ea6238c96ed116e8b2c83c48

"}, {'created': '2018-01-19 08:02:37.000000000', 'message': "Remove oslo config global conf dependency

Ceilometer in Ocata made several changes to
move away from  oslo config's global conf.
Instead ceilometer/service.py now creates a
oslo config object that gets passed to the
publisher.

To keep up with the changes had to make
the following changes in monasca-ceilometer
1.) Monasca Publisher now extends
ConfigPublisherBase, with conf as argument
2.) monasca_client now takes conf as an
argument during intialization.
3.) Added monasca_ceilometer_opts to
intialize all ConfigOpts. This will have
to be regiested in ceilometer/opts.py.
(will need a additional line in opts.py)
4.) Introduced three new properties
service_username, service_password and
service_auth_url since username, password
and auth_url were removed from
[service_credentials] section.
5.) Added api/health.py, service.py
and opts.py from ceilometer code base
which were modified to read
monasca ceilometer options via
monasca_ceilometer_opts.py

List of Ceilometer changes to remove
global conf
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384834
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384624
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/386025

This change also modifies test-requirements.txt
to bring this master branch up to the stable/pike
version of ceilometer, and python-monascaclient
up to 1.7.1 (pike).

Change-Id: Ieb7962a50fdb5d12ea6238c96ed116e8b2c83c48

Change-Id: Ieb7962a50fdb5d12ea6238c96ed116e8b2c83c48
"}, {'created': '2018-01-21 21:34:00.000000000', 'message': "Remove oslo config global conf dependency

Ceilometer in Ocata made several changes to
move away from  oslo config's global conf.
Instead ceilometer/service.py now creates a
oslo config object that gets passed to the
publisher.

To keep up with the changes had to make
the following changes in monasca-ceilometer
1.) Monasca Publisher now extends
ConfigPublisherBase, with conf as argument
2.) monasca_client now takes conf as an
argument during intialization.
3.) Added monasca_ceilometer_opts to
intialize all ConfigOpts. This will have
to be regiested in ceilometer/opts.py.
(will need a additional line in opts.py)
4.) Introduced three new properties
service_username, service_password and
service_auth_url since username, password
and auth_url were removed from
[service_credentials] section.
5.) Added api/health.py, service.py
and opts.py from ceilometer code base
which were modified to read
monasca ceilometer options via
monasca_ceilometer_opts.py
6.) Added ostestr to test requirements
and updated tox.ini to run tests in
serial (to avoid problems with
singleton mapping classes, stepping
on each other test values  when
run in parallel)

List of Ceilometer changes to remove
global conf
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384834
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384624
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/386025

This change also modifies test-requirements.txt
to bring this master branch up to the stable/pike
version of ceilometer, and python-monascaclient
up to 1.7.1 (pike).

Change-Id: Ieb7962a50fdb5d12ea6238c96ed116e8b2c83c48

commit_message:
Remove oslo config global conf dependency

Ceilometer in Ocata made several changes to
move away from  oslo config's global conf.
Instead ceilometer/service.py now creates a
oslo config object that gets passed to the
publisher.

To keep up with the changes had to make
the following changes in monasca-ceilometer
1.) Monasca Publisher now extends
ConfigPublisherBase, with conf as argument
2.) monasca_client now takes conf as an
argument during intialization.
3.) Added monasca_ceilometer_opts to
intialize all ConfigOpts. This will have
to be regiested in ceilometer/opts.py.
(will need a additional line in opts.py)
4.) Introduced three new properties
service_username, service_password and
service_auth_url since username, password
and auth_url were removed from
[service_credentials] section.
5.) Added api/health.py, service.py
and opts.py from ceilometer code base
which were modified to read
monasca ceilometer options via
monasca_ceilometer_opts.py
6.) Added ostestr to test requirements
and updated tox.ini to run tests in
serial (to avoid problems with
singleton mapping classes, stepping
on each other test values  when
run in parallel)

List of Ceilometer changes to remove
global conf
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384834
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384624
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/386025

This change also modifies test-requirements.txt
to bring this master branch up to the stable/pike
version of ceilometer, and python-monascaclient
up to 1.7.1 (pike).

Change-Id: Ieb7962a50fdb5d12ea6238c96ed116e8b2c83c48

commit_message:
Restrict VNF deletion, if part of Active NS

VNF should not be allowed to delete separately,
if part of an active NS.

Change-Id: I3421a311c7a8dcc6c9c4eec2265c6384370c0972
Closes-Bug: #1691363

No new features.

commit_message:
Security group deletion

1. What is the problem?

A security group(sg) may map to several local sg in local neutron.
During the deletion of sg local neutron may recreate the sg if it
recieve a get-request of sg.

2. What is the solution to the problem?

The solution to resource deleting is covered in
specs/queens/resource deleting.rst

3. What the features to be implemented in the Tricircle to realize the solution?
No new features.

Change-Id: Ia537c8a32f527e64d733b2a0bd7c90b400cd747f

Update ValueError message

The strings in oslo_utils.strutils.TRUE_STRINGS and
oslo_utils.strutils.FALSE_STRINGS can coverted to bool
by os_utils.bool_from_string.

Signed-off-by: pengdake <19921207pq@gmail.com>

Handle os-api-ref in build-api-ref job

building when files in os_api_ref change.

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary setup_clients methods

Changed files have service clients aliases
and unnecessary setup_methods. These should
use service clients variable defined in base class.

Change-Id: Id8ca6a62f3658c78e238a11eeadf23946d90f8f2

commit_message:
Add a active-standby mode memcached in haproxy

Memcached do not support cluster. Then make it work in active-standby
mode. This will be helpful to implement high available when using memcached
as tooz backend.

Change-Id: I13722111d8b8d5b066e9a85d4c8d1679704c8caa

[{'created': '2017-11-06 18:23:29.000000000', 'message': 'Make RBAC Policy allowed values visible

For entirely spurious reasons, RBAC Policies were validated using a custom
validate() method that is invisible to the user instead of using
constraints to validate values in a way consistent with all other resource
types, and that would appear in the API documentation. This rectifies that
error and improves the documentation and error reporting.

Change-Id: I0cde2fe5dd5c57c6f5a367d0405bcffad01678fa
'}, {'created': '2017-11-06 20:10:15.000000000', 'message': 'Document RBAC Policy allowed values

For entirely spurious reasons, RBAC Policies were validated using a custom
validate() method that is invisible to the user instead of using
constraints to validate values in a way consistent with all other resource
types, and that would appear in the API documentation. This rectifies that
error and improves the documentation and error reporting.

Change-Id: I0cde2fe5dd5c57c6f5a367d0405bcffad01678fa
'}]
commit_message:
Document RBAC Policy allowed values

For entirely spurious reasons, RBAC Policies were validated using a custom
validate() method that is invisible to the user instead of using
constraints to validate values in a way consistent with all other resource
types, and that would appear in the API documentation. This rectifies that
error and improves the documentation and error reporting.

Change-Id: I0cde2fe5dd5c57c6f5a367d0405bcffad01678fa

commit_message:
ipv4 address for overcloud nodes in ssh.config.ansible

The ansible_fqdn variable appears to be getting
overwritten during fact gathering.  Create a unique
variable to define the default address for overcloud
nodes.

Closes-Bug: #1742528
Change-Id: I85a2e76c4582e3a95f407e2d1edbf6051bf3525b

commit_message:
Able to change admin state for all resources

Also make the workflow more independent and predictable. Previously it
is using the extensible workflow methods and does not make a copy of
a step for each workflow, which would mess up with each other.

Change-Id: I2e808282ed3c180105978f359fff7558d9e78ca7
Story: 1713844
Task: 5361

commit_message:
Convert bashate-python36-fedora-26 to Zuul v3

Convert the job to native Zuul v3. The repo does not use
upper-constraints, so there's no  need to use openstack/requirements.

Rename the job to follow our naming pattern for tox jobs.

Also, remove project name from stanza, it's not needed for in-tree
configuration anymore.

Change-Id: If79bc60b7e60d172c64dee1cd7900853aa7a1f37

commit_message:
Fix senlin tempest plugin to work properly

* moved testfiles into tests subdirectory
* fix basepath for plugin
* fix entrypoint
* provide steps in README to install and use senlin-tempest-plugin
* add config option when creating clusters to test node naming
* removed test drivers
* fix various test cases
* Replace deprecated aliases 'os'/'os_adm' with 'os_primary'/'os_admin'

Change-Id: I7551783a4e9b2194559c3a400594227b2d9c26b9

There has an error message with " 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in

Chinese availability_zone.
Then I found the str(value) send an error if the value is u'\u53ef\u7528\u52ff\u5220'
in schema.py when validate the profile. I add a if to judge the value is

commit_message:
Fix the bug that could not create a profile with Chinese availability_zone

There has an error message with " 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in
 position 0-1: ordinal not in range(128)" when I create a profile with
Chinese availability_zone.
Then I found the str(value) send an error if the value is u'\u53ef\u7528\u52ff\u5220'
in schema.py when validate the profile. I add a if to judge the value is
unicode or not.

Closes-Bug: #1739877

commit_message:
Use DocumentedRuleDefault instead of RuleDefault

The DocumentedRuleDefault class has advantages over the RuleDefault
class because it allows project developers the opportunity to
describe how policies map to actual APIs. This makes things a lot
easier for operators trying to understand policies for a given
project, and doesn't require them to dig in the code to figure out
what they protect.

Polices are also splitted into small files for easier maintainance.

This is part of an effort to move policy and documentation of policy
into code, treating it like configuration.

bp policy-and-docs-in-code

Co-Authored-By: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ifcdbccae7350ec69ad7d92197b9bfca8aeb8352b

commit_message:
Block oslo.serialization 2.21.2, 2.22.0, 2.23.0

Commit c1a7079c26d27a2e46cca26963d3d9aa040bdbe8 breaks Glance's unit
test. Revert patch in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/534736/ so
block version with this commit.

Change-Id: Ic15d265b5417f2778a160c0b34322f1427e2decd
Related-Bug: #1728368

commit_message:
Remove local subclass of Object and ObjectField

These two classes were temporary hacks due to bugs in upstream
oslo.versionedobjects. With current global requirements setting version
of oslo.versionedobjects to 1.28, this is no longer needed.

Change-Id: Icec8d9689cd5634c9f29bfdd8899126853cd6550

commit_message:
[Urgent] fix unit test errors

This patch fixes two unit test errors. One is "ipv6_address_mode not
found", the other is "has no attribute type_manager". The first error
is addressed by the previous patch[1] but cannot be merged due to the
second error, so this patch address these two errors at the same time.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/532417/

Change-Id: Ibda5b5870fa8466b3f5a886ee0c16a2ec8c74abc

subject: Improve vm name by os.nova.server created
messages:
[{'account_id': 25661, 'date': '2017-05-02 08:16:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2017-05-02 08:38:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Overall, the idea looks good to me. However, I am feeling uncomfortable that the name is not controlled by users.

Another option (an idea borrowed from Kubernetes) is to add a property to the Server profile (e.g. 'name_prefix') which defines the base name for the instances and then Senlin generates a suffix to make the name unique.

When speaking of name uniqueness, it seems reasonable and clear enough to append the node index (in string format) to the base name. Another option is to append a short, random string as we have been doing to nodes and clusters.

All these behaviors should be exposed to at least admins for customization. Name generation with index is only meaningful for cluster nodes, so the configuration option should be a profile property. It should be modeled as a cluster configuration instead.

Following this thought, I am now thinking of something like this:

   POST /v1/clusters/<cluster_id>/configs
   BODY:
      {"name_nodes_with_index": true}

or,

   POST /v1/clusters
   BODY:
     {
        "cluster": {
          "name": "my_cluster",
          "profile_id": "my_profile_id",
          "configs": {
            "name_node_with_index": true
          }
        }
      }

The former one implies a new API resource, but it is more flexible. The latter one is about a new cluster property, which means more code churn to existing logics.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-05-02 08:56:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-senlin-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/gate-senlin-docs-ubuntu-xenial/de24e4e//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 18s
- gate-senlin-pep8-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/gate-senlin-pep8-ubuntu-xenial/eb8442e/ : SUCCESS in 3m 06s
- gate-senlin-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/gate-senlin-python27-ubuntu-xenial/869d386/ : SUCCESS in 3m 32s
- gate-senlin-python35 http://logs.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/gate-senlin-python35/3e69f2d/ : SUCCESS in 3m 27s
- senlin-coverage-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/senlin-coverage-ubuntu-xenial-nv/ee58123/ : SUCCESS in 5m 19s (non-voting)
- gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py27-api http://logs.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py27-api/620031c/ : SUCCESS in 38m 08s
- gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py35-api-nv http://logs.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py35-api-nv/716ff16/ : FAILURE in 23m 02s (non-voting)
- gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py27-functional http://logs.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py27-functional/9fde71c/ : SUCCESS in 30m 24s
- gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py35-functional-nv http://logs.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py35-functional-nv/2b9cfde/ : FAILURE in 15m 57s (non-voting)
- gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py27-integration-nv http://logs.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py27-integration-nv/2ebebea/ : FAILURE in 22m 32s (non-voting)
- gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py35-integration-nv http://logs.openstack.org/73/461673/1/check/gate-senlin-dsvm-tempest-py35-integration-nv/5c15e38/ : FAILURE in 19m 25s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 25661, 'date': '2017-05-02 09:48:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Overall, the idea looks good to me. However, I am feeling
 > uncomfortable that the name is not controlled by users.
 > 
 > Another option (an idea borrowed from Kubernetes) is to add a
 > property to the Server profile (e.g. 'name_prefix') which defines
 > the base name for the instances and then Senlin generates a suffix
 > to make the name unique.
 > 
 > When speaking of name uniqueness, it seems reasonable and clear
 > enough to append the node index (in string format) to the base
 > name. Another option is to append a short, random string as we have
 > been doing to nodes and clusters.
 > 
 > All these behaviors should be exposed to at least admins for
 > customization. Name generation with index is only meaningful for
 > cluster nodes, so the configuration option should be a profile
 > property. It should be modeled as a cluster configuration instead.
 > 
 > Following this thought, I am now thinking of something like this:
 > 
 > POST /v1/clusters/<cluster_id>/configs
 > BODY:
 > {"name_nodes_with_index": true}
 > 
 > or,
 > 
 > POST /v1/clusters
 > BODY:
 > {
 > "cluster": {
 > "name": "my_cluster",
 > "profile_id": "my_profile_id",
 > "configs": {
 > "name_node_with_index": true
 > }
 > }
 > }
 > 
 > The former one implies a new API resource, but it is more flexible.
 > The latter one is about a new cluster property, which means more
 > code churn to existing logics.


Qiming, I almost got it.

Firstly, I add a property 'name_prefix' in Server profile. If user specify name_prefix, I will use name_prefix + suffix as new name.
If not specify  name_prefix, just use name.

Secondly, add a new api to configure cluster. If set name_nodes_with_index value is true, will use node index as suffix,
else use random string as suffix.

Is that right?'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2017-05-02 11:46:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

 > 
 > Secondly, add a new api to configure cluster. If set

 > 
 > Is that right?

 > I don't think we need to support both. Adding a cluster config
 > property might be the right direction to go because we have other
 > requirements that justify such a new property.

All right. Do we need add a new table called cluster_config or cluster_tag to restore these info, or just add column in cluster table?
If we use cluster table still and just add a column called config, I think we dont need add new api, just use cluster update method is ok.'}, {'account_id': 25661, 'date': '2017-05-02 21:36:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Rename zuul v3 job

Rename job to follow naming conventions for a shared global namespace:
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#consistent-naming-for-jobs-with-zuul-v3

Also, remove name from project stanza, it's not needed for in-tree zuul
files anymore.

Keep old name to allow renaming, a followup will remove it.

Needed-By: I2dd2075e41680d7b85d574575a19531599dabf5e
Change-Id: Id2aed659c1fcb7333b7efa4dc0a019d21bdcd51a

subject: Fix the bug that couldn't create a receiver
messages: [{'account_id': 26650, 'date': '2018-01-20 06:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2018-01-22 00:28:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 26576, 'date': '2018-01-22 00:40:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-20 06:27:11.000000000', 'message': 'Fix the bug that couldn't create a receiver

When I create a receiver for a cluster,there has
failed with the error message "HttpException:
Internal Server Error"

Then I found there has not the function get_schema()
in ClusterActionName class and ReceiverType class,
so that raise NotImplementedError() from the class
FieldType of oslo_versionedobjects/fields.py.

Then I add the get_schema() in ClusterActionName and
ReceiverType and fix this bug.

Closes-Bug: #1744426
Change-Id: Ie29e1dffdedb37b117ec698fba434084f5d5f831
'}]
commit_message:
Fix the bug that couldn't create a receiver

When I create a receiver for a cluster,there has
failed with the error message "HttpException:
Internal Server Error"

Then I found there has not the function get_schema()
in ClusterActionName class and ReceiverType class,
so that raise NotImplementedError() from the class
FieldType of oslo_versionedobjects/fields.py.

Then I add the get_schema() in ClusterActionName and
ReceiverType and fix this bug.

Closes-Bug: #1744426
Change-Id: Ie29e1dffdedb37b117ec698fba434084f5d5f831

subject: Use version definition from openstack.version
messages:
[{'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-01-18 14:05:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8257, 'date': '2018-01-18 14:16:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This seems probably fine, but could you expand on "causing some problems
sometimes when invoking sdk apis"? It seems like if we're going to fix something we should know more about why.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-01-18 14:26:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I installed openstack==0.10.0

Then run:
python2
import openstack
print openstack.__version__

Then get the following:
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '__version__'

If I run:
python2
from openstack import version

commit_message:
Use version definition from openstack.version

Having openstack/__init__.py referencing pbr is causing some problems
sometimes when invoking sdk apis. This patch propose using the version
definition from version module under openstack/.

This is a follow up of 2f05a3d0667efa07004c71e13217f1ed6d95b198.

Change-Id: I3117becd0e91514447a426f2fec4d133dd11f404

commit_message:
Remove hack for ubuntu cloud archive

There is a hack here to set up ubuntu cloud archive, pinning it to
mirror.dfw.rax.openstack.org. The mirror-info role seems to be doing
this correctly now though, so let's remove the hack and let things work
normally.

Change-Id: I283cb3452245b64e9492806f06404b484f21c358

commit_message:
add show_version.sh tool

Add a script to make it easy to discover the version of a package
being used in all branches without checking out each branch by hand.

Change-Id: I484c01f24f9f158d85462c45efbaee552f51e116
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

Delete unused status related fields

This patch deletes some status related fields which are not used anymore
in the new state machine.

Partially Implements: blueprint state-machine
Closes-Bug: #1699661

commit_message:
Cleanup test-requirements

python-subunit is not used directly anywhere
and it is dependency of both testrepository
and os-testr
(probably was used by some tox wrapper script before)

commit_message:
Add restart to OSC

This change adds database support to the python-openstackclient
project for the restart command

The trove command restart is now:
    openstack database instance restart

Change-Id: I24eeb001d27eae39be5c33650e9bc04287053c8c
Partially-Implements: blueprint trove-support-in-python-openstackclient

commit_message:
Add tempest-stress project repo

tempest-stress is to perform stress testing of cloud
using tempest. This framework used to be in tempest
earlier but due to tempest scope it had been moved
out of tempest tree.

During queens PTG (even earlier) we discussed to make
it in separate repo.

Needed-By: Ib6fb2eac8568f6e86aae24782bfa6d9cca4fe54c

Change-Id: I063303642f5c99e4ca95d0e02c2360a003688ad6

That's the highest Code-Review score I can give... I don't know enough about MapR to say whether or not there are subtle regressions. I guess the good news is that this new kind of image generation also can self-validate, so going forward regressions will be detected more easily (if I understand it right).

The fact that the scenario tests pass make me comfortable enough for Workflow+1, but I'll wait another day till approving in case someone is still crafting a more incisive review."}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-01-21 17:09:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Workflow+1

The rare case of CR+1 and W+1 together...'}]

missing zuul/main.yaml change'}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2018-01-11 08:27:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2018-01-11 08:39:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > This is part of ironic? Then let's add governance patch and link
 > via needed-by to it, see http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/creators.html

The patch to governance was already merged. Or you mean networking-generic-switch-tempest-plugin?"}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2018-01-11 08:39:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> missing zuul/main.yaml change

Done.'}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2018-01-11 08:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Andreas thanks for review.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-11 08:42:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm waiting for governance change for networking-generic-switch-tempest-plugin ."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-11 08:43:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

If you have initial code, why not import it?

You can import an existing repository including it's history if
you have one. Once the repository is created, importing is not
possible anymore, changes will have to go through the normal review
process.

If you have a lot of history to import, please use the upstream field
instead of creating a repository and then pushing the patches one at a
time. Pushing a large number of related patches all at one time causes
the CI infrastructure to slow down, which impacts work on all of the
other projects using it. After repo creation the infra team will not
push any content to it; this is your only chance to import directly.

Please confirm that starting with empty repo is fine."}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2018-01-11 08:45:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> If you have initial code, why not import it?
 > 
 > You can import an existing repository including it's history if
 > you have one. Once the repository is created, importing is not
 > possible anymore, changes will have to go through the normal review
 > process.
 > 
 > If you have a lot of history to import, please use the upstream
 > field
 > instead of creating a repository and then pushing the patches one
 > at a
 > time. Pushing a large number of related patches all at one time
 > causes
 > the CI infrastructure to slow down, which impacts work on all of
 > the
 > other projects using it. After repo creation the infra team will
 > not
 > push any content to it; this is your only chance to import
 > directly.
 > 
 > Please confirm that starting with empty repo is fine.

Can we import only specific commits from repo? For other openstack projects we split tempest code manually."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-11 09:35:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

yes, you can import parts with history, see git filter-branch'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-01-11 09:38:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Actually, we did import history for ironic tempest plugin. We even imported history from two git trees! See John's script: https://github.com/openstack/ironic-tempest-plugin/blob/master/tools/make-tempest-plugin-repo.sh"}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2018-01-11 10:38:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Actually, we did import history for ironic tempest plugin. We even
 > imported history from two git trees! See John's script:
 > https://github.com/openstack/ironic-tempest-plugin/blob/master/tools/make-tempest-plugin-repo.sh


I know about this script, but I don't think we can use this when creating repo."}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2018-01-11 13:44:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2018-01-16 08:32:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-16 09:16:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

So, what about import?'}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2018-01-19 12:46:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> So, what about import?

I'm sorry just trying to understand what can be done here. So I can create personal repo on github, import only specific commits to that repo, and then define it as upstream when adding networking-generic-switch-tempest-plugin? Am I correct? Is it possible to import part of history without creating separate repo?"}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-19 13:13:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Vasyl, exactly - see the previous comments on how to create a custom repo.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-19 13:41:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

> My understanding is that you want to import with history. Let's -1

Done, please rereview, thanks!"}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-01-21 15:47:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

LGTM, but can't be approved until we have Dimitry's +1 (he's already +1'd the corresponding governance addition, at least)."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-01-21 17:02:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Sure :)

Nice job pre-creating the upstream repository!'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-21 17:04:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

commit_message:
Make meta.find_best_address() more generic

This function now can choose address family with socket.getaddrinfo()
method and there is no need to pass address family as argument to it.

Change-Id: I72b1c1263876f2d047e5e540b72f2550ec73b65c
Story: 2001475
Task: 6213

'}]
commit_message:
Make floating IP to be prefered over fixed when looking for IP

We can assume that floating IP is public IP address in clouds so
floating IPs should be checked first if they can be used to
connect to instance.

Change-Id: I1024d78e68a788bf5a92cb63d008c02180908dfa
Story: 2001475
Task: 6212

[{'created': '2018-01-03 11:02:47.000000000', 'message': 'init-runonce: check OpenStack client version

Debian ships 3.2.1 which is far too old but script is happy as it is
installed. Then errors appear.

Change-Id: I70a9c5ed3a6ef671affb01b1a87a799e23d6b0e2
'}, {'created': '2018-01-21 10:23:07.000000000', 'message': "Install OpenStack client as requirement

Last part of deploying is running 'tools/init-runonce' script which uses
'openstack' client script.

There is a check is 'openstack' client installed but no
version/functionality check. And this is a problem if there is system
wide python-openstackclient installed in old version (like 3.2.1 in
Debian 'stretch'). Script will finish despite generating bunch of errors
and final deployment will lack networking.

Change-Id: I70a9c5ed3a6ef671affb01b1a87a799e23d6b0e2
"}]
commit_message:
Install OpenStack client as requirement

Last part of deploying is running 'tools/init-runonce' script which uses
'openstack' client script.

There is a check is 'openstack' client installed but no
version/functionality check. And this is a problem if there is system
wide python-openstackclient installed in old version (like 3.2.1 in
Debian 'stretch'). Script will finish despite generating bunch of errors
and final deployment will lack networking.

Change-Id: I70a9c5ed3a6ef671affb01b1a87a799e23d6b0e2

commit_message:
Add Constraints support

Constraints is the mechanism that our CI and deployers use to reduce
introduce new libraries into OpenStack in a controlled fashion, ensure
co-installability across the entire OpenStack code base and removed
known bad library releases from consideration.

Adding constraints support to libraries is slightly more complex than
services as the libraries themselves are listed in upper-constraints.txt
which leads to errors that you can't install a specific version and a
constrained version.

This change adds constraints support by also adding a helper script to
edit the constraints to remove openstacksdk.

This work is part of a larger effort from the requirements management
team to enable flexibility in our requirements management while still
documenting and enforcing co-installability.

Change-Id: I72da07d0afd63c3c00805475f8d440c68db704dd

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-12-28 20:09:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

commit_message:
Fix download_object for Python 3

This fixes the following error message when downloading an object to
a file: "TypeError: must be str, not bytes".

Change-Id: I957ad63fb8c92fc3f3cb56e5a51d3be23008e119

[{'created': '2018-01-15 23:47:23.000000000', 'message': "Invert the attribute mapping

requests returns headers in a CaseInsensitiveDict because Headers are
case insensitive. Unfortunately, that only applies to keys, and our
current attribute mapping that we use to consume values from payloads is
{client_name: server_name}, which means we have to go through
shenanigans to get the comparison right.

Invert the mapping returned by _get_mapping and update the logic to
deal with the inversion.

While we're at it, remove _filter_component, as _consume_attrs already
does the same thing and handles the case sensitivity properly.

commit_message:
Invert the attribute mapping

requests returns headers in a CaseInsensitiveDict because Headers are
case insensitive. Unfortunately, that only applies to keys, and our
current attribute mapping that we use to consume values from payloads is
{client_name: server_name}, which means we have to go through
shenanigans to get the comparison right.

Invert the mapping returned by _get_mapping and update the logic to
deal with the inversion.

While we're at it, remove _filter_component, as _consume_attrs already
does the same thing and handles the case sensitivity properly.

Change-Id: Ice38cc31635a364839472248f3814b0c8f65bfe1

[{'created': '2017-09-26 11:45:53.000000000', 'message': 'Update the vip to fqdn

when definition the kolla_internal_fqdn, it should not
the same as kolla_internal_vip_addres, however many vip
exist in configure file, this patch to fix it.

Change-Id: I9ca286610c7b420326925e1363e594919cd021c8
'}]
commit_message:
Update the vip to fqdn

when definition the kolla_internal_fqdn, it should not
the same as kolla_internal_vip_addres, however many vip
exist in configure file, this patch to fix it.

Change-Id: I9ca286610c7b420326925e1363e594919cd021c8

commit_message:
log: augment json records

The ContextFormatter gathers more information about the request than
the JSONFormatter, which is rather opposite to what one might expect.
This patch pulls that logic out into a separate method allowing it to
be reused.

Change-Id: I69063d687648343552e66e47e1e9a55b37eb24c2
Closes-Bug: #1564931

commit_message:
Remove deprecated config options 'resources_prefix'

Config option 'resources_prefix' was deprecated. It is
used by only manila plugin which fix has been commited.

This commit removes this config option and hardcode the
resource prefix as 'tempest'

Change-Id: Idce7af97fe6647e3095b2b626fbacb3446694fbc
Depends-On: I9c140b3a9efabeced7fc26cb1f169ebe6789d88b

commit_message:
Remove obsolete tempest-lib

tempest-lib has been reintegrated into tempest and this repository
already uses tempest instead of tempest-lib. Replace requirements for
tempest-lib with requirements for tempest.

See also
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/qa-specs/specs/tempest/implemented/reintegrate-tempest-lib.html

Change-Id: I2c79aceb98934cda962dcaf13db896d7f55086b8

nimble: handle unicode strings in volume create

currently nimble cinder driver doesn't handle unicode strings
for display_name and display_description

Change-Id: Ic94cbc50d5761c7fc67d2973bed70c70cf6bf769
Closes-Bug: 1732812
(cherry picked from commit 23ac0ab4edd38b91b0c21d5c9e81cd1a7bdddc55)

commit_message:
Fix up to work with 0.6.0 of charms.reactive

charms.reactive deprecates the RelationBase.from_state() class
method.  This is an internal method in charms.reactive and shouldn't
really have been used.

This patch changes to charms.relations.endpoint_from_flag(...) which
essentially does the same thing and will be a more stable API moving
forwards.

Note that from this point on, the library will ONLY work with
charms.reactive 0.6.0 onwards and the modified charms.openstack library.

Change-Id: I6e025438bacd17dfb2a6f61fb8ca274187009c57

commit_message:
Fix up to work with 0.6.0 of charms.reactive

charms.reactive deprecates the RelationBase.from_state() class
method.  This is an internal method in charms.reactive and shouldn't
really have been used.

This patch changes to charms.relations.endpoint_from_flag(...) which
essentially does the same thing and will be a more stable API moving
forwards.

Note that from this point on, the library will ONLY work with
charms.reactive 0.6.0 onwards and the modified charms.openstack library.

Change-Id: I282bf7fc864f9066596c20ba6175283e934e7c12

commit_message:
Fix api-ref for v3 volume group types

This patch is mainly to fix api-ref for v3 volume group types,
including:

1. add description and example for the API: show defaut group type
2. fix parameters: 'is_public' and 'description'
3. remove unused sample file: group-type-show-request.json

Change-Id: I29f160d8ed24473debb345b4ea91ee0545d711b1

[{'created': '2018-01-20 17:41:10.000000000', 'message': 'Remove obsolete tempest-lib

tempest-lib has been reintegrated into tempest and this repository
already uses tempest instead of tempest-lib. Replace requirements for
tempest-lib with requirements for tempest.

See also
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/qa-specs/specs/tempest/implemented/reintegrate-tempest-lib.html

Change-Id: Ia3c3db073136fd491749cb02895012e97650592f
'}]
commit_message:
Remove obsolete tempest-lib

tempest-lib has been reintegrated into tempest and this repository
already uses tempest instead of tempest-lib. Replace requirements for
tempest-lib with requirements for tempest.

See also
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/qa-specs/specs/tempest/implemented/reintegrate-tempest-lib.html

Change-Id: Ia3c3db073136fd491749cb02895012e97650592f

commit_message:
Add events and resources for L3 flavors.

To address the callbacks in L3 flavor drivers for OpenDaylight
new event and resources are added to handle router request.
They are introduced initially in neutron [1]. but neutron-lib
is the right place to have them.

[1].https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523257/

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-19 16:32:33.000000000', 'message': 'Fix server post deploy step with config-download

Due to a misplaced endfor in the j2 template, the deployments.yaml
playbook was only included for the first role. The bogus task playbook
was rendered as:

  - hosts: overcloud
    name: Server Post Deployments
    gather_facts: no
    any_errors_fatal: yes
    tasks:
      - include: Controller/deployments.yaml
        vars:
          force: false
        when: role_name == 'Controller'
        with_items: "{{ Controller_post_deployments|default([]) }}"
    tags:
      - overcloud
      - post_deploy_steps
      - include: Compute/deployments.yaml
        vars:
          force: false
        when: role_name == 'Compute'
        with_items: "{{ Compute_post_deployments|default([]) }}"
    tags:
      - overcloud
      - post_deploy_steps

Change-Id: I625fcaa7c4dcb4f99f30b9d6def293154f4eb7ec
'}]
commit_message:
Fix server post deploy step with config-download

Due to a misplaced endfor in the j2 template, the deployments.yaml
playbook was only included for the first role. The bogus task playbook
was rendered as:

  - hosts: overcloud
    name: Server Post Deployments
    gather_facts: no
    any_errors_fatal: yes
    tasks:
      - include: Controller/deployments.yaml
        vars:
          force: false
        when: role_name == 'Controller'
        with_items: "{{ Controller_post_deployments|default([]) }}"
    tags:
      - overcloud
      - post_deploy_steps
      - include: Compute/deployments.yaml
        vars:
          force: false
        when: role_name == 'Compute'
        with_items: "{{ Compute_post_deployments|default([]) }}"
    tags:
      - overcloud
      - post_deploy_steps

Change-Id: I625fcaa7c4dcb4f99f30b9d6def293154f4eb7ec
